title: Technology and Innovation Lexicon
description: Specialized vocabulary for technology, innovation, and digital transformation

items.definition: Creating radical change by displacing established technologies, markets, or industries
items.example: Streaming services proved disruptive to the traditional broadcasting industry.

items.definition: The capacity of a system to handle growth or increased demand efficiently
items.example: Cloud computing offers unprecedented scalability for growing businesses.

items.definition: A set of rules or procedures for solving problems or processing data
items.example: Social media algorithms determine which content users see in their feeds.

items.definition: The ability of different systems or components to work together seamlessly
items.example: Healthcare systems require interoperability to share patient records securely.

items.definition: A repetition of a process to approach a desired result; a version of a product
items.example: Each iteration of the product incorporated user feedback from the previous version.

items.definition: The delay before a transfer of data begins following an instruction
items.example: 5G networks promise significantly reduced latency compared to 4G.

items.definition: The process of becoming outdated or no longer useful
items.example: Planned obsolescence encourages consumers to upgrade devices regularly.

items.definition: Owned and controlled by a particular company; not open or publicly available
items.example: The company's proprietary software gives them a competitive advantage.
